qas.question: By how many kilometers does the traveling salesman problem seek to classify a route between the 15 largest cities in Germany?
What is one example of an instance that the quantitative answer to the traveling salesman problem fails to answer?

answers.text: round trip through all sites in Milan
asking for a round trip through all sites in Milan whose total length is at most 10 km
a round trip through all sites in Milan whose total length is at most 10 km

qas.question: What does computational complexity theory most specifically seek to answer?
How many miles does the traveling salesman problem seek to classify a route between the 15 smallest cities in Germany?

plausible_answers.text: is of little use for solving other instances of the problem

qas.question: What is the qualitative answer to this particular problem instance?

plausible_answers.text: round trip through all sites in Milan

qas.question: What is one example of an instance that the qualitative answer to the traveling salesman fails to answer?
What does computational simplicity theory most specifically seek to answer?

context: To further highlight the difference between a problem and an instance, consider the following instance of the decision version of the traveling salesman problem: Is there a route of at most <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b3_0>2000<b3_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> kilometres passing through all of Germany's 15 largest cities? The quantitative answer to this particular problem instance <b4_0>is of little use for solving other instances of the problem<b4_0/>, such as <a1_1>asking for <a1_2>a <a1_0><b5_0>round trip through all sites in Milan<b5_0/><a1_0/> whose total length is at most 10 km<a1_2/><a1_1/>. For this reason, complexity theory addresses <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b6_0>computational problems<b6_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> and not particular problem instances.
